docs.lead_paragraph: A decade ago, concern over the country's budget deficits dominated political and economic debates, just as it does now. Many of the same people who now worry that a fiscal disaster is on the horizon envisioned a similar catastrophe in the early 1990's. But last time, in the blink of an eye, the deficits disappeared. In 1992, the budget shortfall was a central issue in the presidential election. By 1998, the government was running a surplus.

headline.main: The Nation; The Deficit Disappeared, but That Was Then

docs.abstract: Factors needed to reverse current budget deficit discussed in light of United States's success in erasing deficit in late 1990's; nearly all analyst agree that success resulted mainly from unexpected boom and other factors over which politicians had no influence; graph of projected and actual budget data; photo (M)
docs.snippet: A decade ago, concern over the country's budget deficits dominated political and economic debates, just as it does now. Many of the same people who now worry that a fiscal disaster is on the horizon envisioned a similar catastrophe in the early...

docs.lead_paragraph: A MIDDLE-AGED woman arrived at the Antelope Valley Hospital in Lancaster, Calif., this summer with a large abscess in her neck. Dr. Lawrence Stock, an emergency-room physician on duty, ordered a CAT scan and antibiotics, but the woman needed a head-and-neck surgeon to drain the abscess. Antelope Valley doesn't have such a surgeon on call, so Dr. Stock transferred the patient to a hospital that does. Two days later, the woman, who lacked insurance, ended up back at Antelope Valley. Dr. Stock said she told him that after spending two days on a gurney virtually untreated at the second hospital, in Los Angeles, about 100 miles away, she decided to come home. The head-and-neck staff surgeon at Antelope Valley then operated on the woman, even though the hospital did not have an on-call arrangement with him.
docs.abstract: Michelle Andrews article on financial problems compromising hospital emergency room care; notes over 500 hospitals have been forced to close emergency departments since 1990, two of every three hospitals sometimes reroute ambulances away from their emergency rooms because of overcrowding and many specialists, unhappy with low payments for treating poor and uninsured, have left hospital staffs; notes new rule will ease requirements for on-call specialty coverage; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: CONSIDER, for a moment, Gen. Wesley K. Clark, newly declared candidate for the Democratic presidential nomination, as a useful Rorschach test for a conflicted party. What did many Democrats see when they looked at General Clark -- and how did that make them feel? They saw a retired military commander who was a critic of the war with Iraq. A decorated hero from the South who could not be dismissed as some outside-the-mainstream, 60's throwback, yet was willing to confront President Bush on foreign policy. A man who was not only right, but maybe, just maybe, electable. And it made them feel . . . happy.

headline.main: The Nation: Hearts or Minds; The Fight for the Democratic Party

docs.abstract: Democratic Party seen torn between its desire to speak, clearly and without apology, about its beliefs and its desire to put together electoral majority in polarized nation to defeat Pres Bush and return to power; old struggle within party over whether to speak to great American middle or to each other has resurfaced with each new generation of activists and strategists since old New Deal coalition came unstuck in 1960's; photos (M)
docs.snippet: CONSIDER, for a moment, Gen. Wesley K. Clark, newly declared candidate for the Democratic presidential nomination, as a useful Rorschach test for a conflicted party. What did many Democrats see when they looked at General Clark -- and how did that...

docs.lead_paragraph: DURING the spring, J. Robert Carr was running a boutique law firm specializing in employment and labor law when he was offered a senior position at a trade association. His law practice was satisfying, he said, but the offer was just too good to pass up. So, in May, he became a vice president of the association, the Society for Human Resource Management. At a time when tens of thousands of workers are starting out on their own, some seasoned entrepreneurs are finding that the independent life, while rewarding, can be too difficult. Whether it is the limited support staff, the rising cost of employee benefits or the difficulty of getting work from cost-cutting companies, life for some entrepreneurs -- or lawyers or doctors in private practice -- is more stressful than it has been in years. As a result, some are deciding that the corporate world looks more appealing.

headline.main: Executive Life; Finding Freedom In the Corporate Life

docs.abstract: Some entrepreneurs and professionals in private practice are finding life too stressful and are taking positions in corporate world; executive recruiters say corporate positions can offer greater income and job security than entrepreneurial jobs; photo (M)
docs.snippet: DURING the spring, J. Robert Carr was running a boutique law firm specializing in employment and labor law when he was offered a senior position at a trade association. His law practice was satisfying, he said, but the offer was just too good to pass...

docs.lead_paragraph: EXACTLY one year ago, Peter Nigrini, then my boyfriend, woke up with his arm swollen to the size of a small tree trunk. I suggested that he see a doctor right away, but he demurred. He was too busy with work -- he's a freelance theatrical designer -- and didn't think it was too serious anyway. ''I hadn't been sick since college,'' said Peter, who was 31 at the time and otherwise in good health. Two days later, he ended up in the hospital emergency room. The doctors said that he had a blood clot in his left shoulder, caused by a vein squeezed between his first rib and collarbone, and eventually performed surgery to remove the rib. His two-week stay at the hospital came to $77,000, and because he had no health insurance he would have to pay for it all himself.
docs.abstract: Abby Ellin article on risky game played by many middle-class young people unable to afford health insurance; cites relatively low-cost insurance options (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: On the third day of his campaign, Gen. Wesley K. Clark struggled today to clarify his statement on Thursday that he would ''probably'' have voted for the Congressional resolution authorizing the invasion of Iraq. General Clark, a former NATO commander who has retired from the Army, never denied making the statement in an interview with four reporters on his chartered plane. But he seemed stunned by the headlines that it generated, as supporters worried that he had undercut his position as an antiwar candidate with military bona fides.

headline.main: Clark Explains Statement on Authorization for Iraq War

docs.abstract: Gen Wesley K Clark, opening campaign in Iowa for Democratic presidential nomination, struggles to clarify his statement that he would 'probably' have voted for Congressional resolution authorizing Iraq invasion; seems stunned by headlines comment has generated, as supporters worry that he has undercut self as antiwar candidate with military bona fides; holds he would not have voted for war, but for leverage for United States to avoid war; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Hurricane Isabel petered out over Canada last night, leaving a wide scar of destruction: nearly two dozen deaths, flooded cities in Virginia and Maryland, millions of people without power and tens of thousands of fallen trees that punctured roofs and blocked roads from North Carolina to New Jersey. As people on North Carolina's Outer Banks began cleaning up, residents of Baltimore were forced to flee the rising waters of a storm-swollen Chesapeake Bay. The waters reached six feet in places before receding yesterday afternoon, leaving neighborhoods looking like Venice as people used rafts and kayaks to maneuver the narrow streets.

headline.main: Storm Leaves Nearly Two Dozen Dead and Millions Without Power

docs.abstract: Hurricane Isabel peters out over Canada, leaving wide scar of destruction: 23 deaths, flooded cities in Virginia and Maryland, millions of people without power and tens of thousands of fallen trees on roofs and roads from North Carolina to New Jersey; Baltimore residents flee rising Chesapeake Bay waters, which reach six feet in places before receding; people use rafts and kayaks to maneuver narrow streets; Potomac River floods stores and homes in historic Old Town district, Alexandria, Va; forecasters expect flooding in parts of central and northern Virginia and northern Maryland as rivers crest; most of deaths attributed to storm were result of traffic accidents or from trees toppling onto cars or houses; Pres Bush declares Maryland disaster area at request of Gov Robert L Ehrlich Jr; had already designated North Carolina and Virginia disaster areas; Insurance Information Institute projects $1 billion in property losses covered by private insurance, not including flood damage; Washington, DC, is quiet, with federal government shut down for second day; many major intersections are blocked by downed trees and much of city is without power; map; photos (M)

byline.original: By JAMES DAO and JENNIFER 8. LEE; Abby Goodnough contributed to this article

docs.lead_paragraph: Conventional wisdom has it that health care is a defensive investment. When the overall economy weakens, people still take their medicine and go to the hospital for surgery, so investors tend to favor the stocks of drug companies and hospital chains. But several mutual fund managers say the experience of the last economic downturn has made them question their previous assumptions. The most recent information from Medicare -- showing that billings from hospitals dropped nearly 4 percent in August compared with the year earlier -- is adding to investors' concerns that hospitals' volumes, and therefore revenues, are not impervious to the ebbs and flows of the economy.

headline.main: Rethinking Health Care as a Haven for Investors

docs.abstract: Study of Medicare data has led some analysts to challenge conventional wisdom that health care sector is a safe haven for investors during economic downturns; proponents of view argue that increased economic sensitivity of sector may be result of consumers' need to shoulder increased share of own costs through copayments and deductibles; skeptics contend that sector, while maturing, continues to be valid defensive play and operates independently of economic cycles; many portfolio managers recommend that hospital and drug stocks be analyzed by company fundamentals rather than industry characteristics; graph (M)
docs.snippet: Conventional wisdom has it that health care is a defensive investment. When the overall economy weakens, people still take their medicine and go to the hospital for surgery, so investors tend to favor the stocks of drug companies and hospital chains....

docs.lead_paragraph: The Suffolk County executive, Robert F. Gaffney, yesterday proposed a $2.4 billion budget for next year with $175 million in new spending and some property tax increases. The average homeowner's annual county tax bill would rise between $25.65 and $44.82 in the five western towns and drop about $1 in the five eastern towns, he said. The difference arises because western towns are taxed for the county police, while the eastern towns pay for the local police in their town and village taxes.

headline.main: Suffolk Executive Proposes Tax Increases in Some Towns

docs.abstract: Suffolk County (NY) Executive Robert F Gaffney proposes $2.4 billion budget that will raise average homeowner's annual county tax by more than $25.65 in five towns (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The United States' military base in Gardez, Afghanistan -- its perimeter marked by a small woodshed with the words Crack House painted over but still visible -- straddles the smooth asphalt main road that leads southeast. For the Americans, blocking the road helps create a ''safe'' radius around their base. For Afghans, however, it creates an inconvenient detour. When the main road is rejoined, it soon offers up the ''customs inspectors'' of a renegade Afghan commander taxing all new cars that pass. The Americans do nothing about this, local residents say.

headline.main: 2 U.S. Fronts: Quick Wars, but Bloody Peace
headline.kicker: THE STRUGGLE FOR IRAQ: THE NEXT PHASE

docs.abstract: United States is embarked on two ambitious projects: simultaneous pacification and rebuilding of Afghanistan and Iraq, where rapid military victories have been followed by murkier, bloodier peace; Bush administration cites progress in both countries--removal of Taliban and its ally Al Qaeda in Afghanistan, overthrow of Baathists in Iraq, liberation of millions of people in each country from oppressive governments, taking of fight to terrorists on soil there they found havens; in Afghanistan, even American officials concede that sense of alienation and disappointment may be helping to nourish boldest regrouping yet by supporters of Taliban; American military bases are being attacked and bands of Taliban are harassing men who do not grow beards; in Iraq, there are daily attacks on American soldiers by foreign fighters, Saddam Hussein loyalists and even ordinary Iraqis increasingly hostile to American occupation; militant Islamic extremism, in its Afghan and Iraqi guises, is proving to be ideology that can be contained but not defeated; cost of occupation of both countries over next year is now put at $87 billion; in neither country does exit for American troops appear feasible in foreseeable future; detailed examination of situation in both countries; chart showing costs of rebuilding; photos; map (L)
